notes.text: Updated rhvm-appliance packages that fix several bugs and add various enhancements are now available.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
Updated rhvm-appliance packages that fix several bugs and add various enhancements are now available.

The RHVM Appliance automates the process of installing and configuring the Red Hat Virtualization Manager. The appliance is available to download as an OVA file from the Customer Portal

In this release, support has been added for OpenSCAP security profiles that can be enabled during self-hosted engine deployment. (BZ#1392051)
notes.title: Details

cwe.name: Exposure of Sensitive Information to an Unauthorized Actor

notes.text: A microprocessor side-channel vulnerability was found on SMT (e.g, Hyper-Threading) architectures. An attacker running a malicious process on the same core of the processor as the victim process can extract certain secret information.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: openssl: Side-channel vulnerability on SMT/Hyper-Threading architectures (PortSmash)
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text: This is a timing side-channel flaw on processors which implement SMT/Hyper-Threading architectures. It can result in leakage of secret data in applications such as OpenSSL that has secret dependent control flow at any granularity level. In order to exploit this flaw, the attacker needs to run a malicious process on the same core of the processor as the victim process.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
Before applying this update, make sure all previously released errata
relevant to your system have been applied.

For details on how to apply this update, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/2974891

At this time Red Hat Engineering is working on patches for openssl package in Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 to address this issue.  Until fixes are available, users are advised to review the guidance supplied in the L1 Terminal Fault vulnerability article: https://access.redhat.com/security/vulnerabilities/L1TF and decide what their exposure across shared CPU threads are and act accordingly.

vulnerabilities.title: openssl: Side-channel vulnerability on SMT/Hyper-Threading architectures (PortSmash)
